triples.evidence: This principle-detecting paired pulses and building lines of response-is the foundation of PET imaging.
Whenever a coincidence is confirmed, the system draws what we call a line of response between the two detectors.
By collecting many such lines from annihilations throughout the body, we can reconstruct a full three-dimensional image of tracer distribution inside the patient.

evidence: The key idea is that we are not looking at a single detector alone. Instead, we compare signals across pairs of detectors.
Whenever a coincidence is confirmed, the system draws what we call a line of response between the two detectors.
This principle-detecting paired pulses and building lines of response-is the foundation of PET imaging.

If detector i and detector j, located opposite one another, both register a pulse at nearly the same instant, and if both pulses have the correct energy-around 511 keV-then we know with high confidence that a true annihilation event occurred along the line connecting those two detectors.
